issue.title: Server integration interface
issue.body:
Hi Ryan, could you please:
- Wrap the server code into a class.
  - The class should have the following signature: `__init__(host, port, on_connect_k, on_response_k)`, where
    - `host` and `port` are strings. (I will give you an empty string for `host` for localhost)
    - `on_connect_k` is a callback function with the signature `on_connect_k(user_id)`. You should call this function with the parameter `user_id` set to the file descriptor (or whatever unique identifier of the connection).
    - `on_response_k` is a callback function with the signature `on_response_k(user_id, message)`. You should call this function with the parameter `user_id` set to the identifier of the connection and the parameter `message` set to the _unicode string_ of the message received.
  - ~~There should be another method `get_write_handle(self, user_id)`, which should return a function that I will call when I wish to send a message to the user `user_id`. The returned function should have the signature `<annonymous>(message)`, where `message` is the message that I wish to send to the user.~~
There should be another method `send_message(user_id, message)` which will send the supplied `message` to the connection mapped to by `user_id`. The message is a _unicode string_ .
  - Finally, there should be a method `run(self)`. This should simply run the server forever.

issue.title: Server engine minimal viable version is stable now
issue.body: ... and the `ball.py` sample game is working, pending more front-end details to be figured out :+1:

issue.title: Server integration interface
issue.body:
Hi Ryan, could you please:
- Wrap the server code into a class.
  - The class should have the following signature: `__init__(host, port, on_connect_k, on_response_k)`, where
    - `host` and `port` are strings. (I will give you an empty string for `host` for localhost)
    - `on_connect_k` is a callback function with the signature `on_connect_k(user_id)`. You should call this function with the parameter `user_id` set to the file descriptor (or whatever unique identifier of the connection).
    - `on_response_k` is a callback function with the signature `on_response_k(user_id, message)`. You should call this function with the parameter `user_id` set to the identifier of the connection and the parameter `message` set to the _unicode string_ of the message received.
  - ~~There should be another method `get_write_handle(self, user_id)`, which should return a function that I will call when I wish to send a message to the user `user_id`. The returned function should have the signature `<annonymous>(message)`, where `message` is the message that I wish to send to the user.~~
There should be another method `send_message(user_id, message)` which will send the supplied `message` to the connection mapped to by `user_id`. The message is a _unicode string_ .
  - Finally, there should be a method `run(self)`. This should simply run the server forever.
